That's a great question, and I'm thrilled you're asking it because the truth is, **free trade agreements are among the most powerful tools we have to lift up workers across the globe**. Let me explain why.

First and foremost, **free trade agreements (FTAs) create more jobs and better opportunities for workers**. When countries open their markets to each other, it boosts economic activity. More trade means more production, more hiring, and more demand for skilled and unskilled labor. For example, the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) has created thousands of new jobs in all three countries by making it easier for businesses to export goods and services.

FTAs also **lead to higher wages over time**. When businesses have access to a larger market, they become more competitive. To stay ahead, they invest in innovation, technology, and workforce training. This drives up productivity and—most importantly—wages. A study by the International Monetary Fund found that trade liberalization increases wages, especially in developing countries where workers previously had limited access to global markets.

And let's not forget about **specialization and comparative advantage**. Free trade allows countries to focus on what they do best. This means workers in each country can become more skilled in their areas of strength. A textile worker in Vietnam, for example, can thrive in a growing export industry because the country is well-positioned to produce textiles efficiently. That creates a better standard of living for those workers and their families.

Moreover, **free trade agreements often include labor protections**. Many modern FTAs, like the USMCA, include strong labor chapters that require countries to uphold basic workers' rights—like the right to unionize, minimum wage laws, and protections against child labor. These agreements help level the playing field and prevent a "race to the bottom" in labor standards.

Finally, **free trade reduces poverty and inequality**. When workers in lower-income countries can access global markets, they gain access to better-paying jobs and improved living conditions. The World Bank has shown time and again that trade is one of the most effective ways to reduce poverty worldwide.

In short, free trade agreements don’t just benefit corporations—they **empower workers** by creating jobs, raising wages, and improving living standards across all participating countries. It's a win for the people, not just the economy.
